description: We got catering at work and everyone scarfed it down almost immediately. Even the people who opted out changed their minds once word got around. We got panang curry, pad Thai w/ shrimp, spicy eggplant, som tum, and jasmine rice. Delish!! :)
author: Myra Y.

description:
I'm a person who gives lots of chances and orders a variety of dishes to test out the caliber of a restaurant before giving up and realizing I've wasted a lot of money -- sometimes with much regret.

With CLG, I would give it 2.5 stars if I could. The boat noodles and angel wings are solid and delivery is great. However, the rest of the menu falls short. Everything is just a little bit bland and has flavors it shouldn't have if you know what authentic Thai food (or even Americanized Thai food) should taste like.

Pad See Ew -- overwhelmed by sesame oil and not much of anything else. I can eat anything and I didn't even want another bite.

Laarb Gai -- Not right at all. Stay way from this soupy and stringy imposter if you're a fan of real laarb.

Yum Woon Sen -- not at all what's it's suppose to be. Instead of being a refreshing noodle salad, it's a warm soppy mess, and again with no flavor.

Thai Basil Chicken -- OK. Smells a bit like detergent but it's the Thai basil! It's nothing fantastic but is just OK if you want some minced meat in sauce to put over rice.

Thai Boat Noodles -- The only reason I order food from CLG. I've had better but this is just good enough to come back for more, especially with the lack of good Pho restaurants in SF.
author: Farm S.

description:
The potential was there...but then you lost me...you really lost me...

Mark J is heading off to San Diego (he's checking out places to move to so when the witness protection program finally accepts him and he can ditch me, he'll be able to tell them where he wants to move to.) But in the meantime, he has to hang out with me. Lunch? Why yes Mark...that sounds good.

We sit down, and there's one person there. We place our order and ask for a glass of water each. Like five minutes later...BAM! The place is swarming with people. WTF mate?

So we wait...and then we wait some more. Do a little more waiting. FINALLY! After about 10 or 15 minutes, she brings out our waters.

I think that she took so long because I jokingly said that I was part camel and that I had humps full of water and could last for days. Ok...that is so not true so I'm sorry if that's what you thought...

Water comes, we drink...blah blah blah. The food (I ordered the mango curry) was actually quite tasty...which is why I went with the 3 stars instead of the 2 that I was thinking about. 

Overall, it's apaprently hit or miss with this place...sometimes good food, sometimes not. Sometimes busy, sometimes not. Ya never really know...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Love that this little place is walking distance to work, and I don't have to beg the waitstaff to make the food "Thai spicy".  (Side note: why is it that so many Thai places in the city seem to think that sugar is a suitable substitute for actual spices?  It didn't work for Cantonese food, won't work here.)

The rice places and noodles at this place taste authentically Thai enough that it reminds me of lunch when I actually lived in Thailand.  Most Thai places serve food that just make me angry.

Someone needs to tell these guys that ventilation is highly recommended in the kitchen when you are constantly stir frying.  I am resigned to smell my lunch on my clothes when going for Korean bbq and Indian, but Thai?
author: Lorin Y.

description:
The girls who work here are really sweet so I feel a slight tinge of guilt for a less than stellar review. The atmosphere is decent enough; cozy and quiet enough to give you a sense of being away from the bustle of the city.

The food is definitely average by way of Thai food, probably below if you take to go and let it sit. I think the main faults are that it's greasier than necessary and blander than I prefer. Due to sheer convenience of CLG's location, I used get spicy noodles or some type of curry quite often. Appetizers are a bad value; too expensive and small portions. Call ahead to order if you must.
author: Claire C.

description:
Seriously? How do they stay in business by serving this kind of food?  

Maybe the place is really cute? Maybe the waiters are all top-model looking AND nice guys? I don't know - because I ordered in via grubhub while working late in the office. Hence, I can't speak for the service or decor. However, I can tell you that the price here is pretty average for Thai restaurants in the city, and the food here is way sub-par, and that's putting it nicely. The crab fried rice tasted like a packaged microwave-and-ready-to-eat fried rice....Thai BBQ beef (about $10) tasted like....maybe food served in jail would taste like this? I mean, the dorm food was slightly better than this. 

Never again.
author: Nana N.

description:
CLG, 

I really wanted to like you and hoped that you'd fulfill my every Thai craving that The Monkey and Cha-Am could not measure up to... 

On my first visit, you forgot the eggplant in my green curry. Upon my second visit, you cheated on me with American broccoli when the menu specified Chinese broccoli. I'm not high-maintenance, I'd just like to get what I've been promised. 

And today, your final offense, my Spicy String Bean dish tasted like $5 Chinese takeout... and I paid $9. 

 I think it's time we moved on. It's not you... it's me.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Happened to walk by and decided to stop in for dinner! SO glad we did! I had the Yen Ta Fo -a delicious seafood soup with super fresh noodles. Just the thing for a chilly evening. My hubby had the Phad Thai and we shared the spring rolls. Everything was fresh and piping hot.  The staff was nice and friendly.  

The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is that it seemed as if the delivery business was the priority and the staging area for ordering, packing plastic bags to-go and sending the delivery guy out the door was taking up half of the cafe.  Also, an annoying Christmas CD with only 5 songs was on repeat...We were the only customers actually eating in the cafe. So, in all, great food, but not the most conducive atmosphere for a dinner date.  I think we'll order delivery next time.
author: Julie D.

description:
Great things come in small packages.  CLG is a perfect example - it's ridiculously small but serves such great food. I tried the Tom Yum soup with chicken, the Chili and Garlic Chicken Lunch Plate, and the BBQ Chicken over Fried Rice lunch plate.  Everything was delicious and fairly priced.  I took some soup home, and although I do wish the portions were bigger (takeout tends to be my version of grocery shopping), it's still worth it. 

It seems that there are a fair few regulars that frequent the spot and treat it as their turf - I would go just before lunch or around 1 PM in order to avoid the rush and territorial lunch predators. :)
author: Maulie D.

description:
I am all for yummy Thai places that DELIVER in my neighborhood! We wanted to stay in and watch the Olympics so I thought I'd try ordering from this place - I've seen their delivery car outside my building a couple times recently.

The good: the food is very fresh, light and well prepared. They have some unique noodle and noodle soup dishes on their menu which are executed very well.

The bad: delivery time was over an hour. Bleh. Don't they know I have low blood sugar and can get very cranky when hungry?!

Still, I definitely recommend this place as a takeout or delivery option in SoMa!
author: Deb I.

description:
I've been here twice already, and it opened MONDAY!

Once for Brown Rice to compliment my bomb as indian food that I got from Trader Joe's.  Let's just say 2.50 for brown rice is ridiculous. 

Today I had the Beef Noodle Soup, which was pretty tasty, it need a little salt, but all together a great lunch for under 8 bucks.

The lady in there has a little attitude, and "accidently" charged me 9 bucks, but I was too smart for her and made her correct. Nice try lady....but no Cigar.
author: Adam L.

description: A bit pricy for the small amount but everything I've had is tasty. I've had many things both there and take-away because I work nearby.
author: Dee K.

description:
It's more like 3.5.  CLG is mine and my coworkers spot for Thai food.  The food is consistently tasty and the prices are reasonable.  I usually have the fried chicken over white rice (usually over fried rice) which is always good.  My coworker had the Thai BBQ chicken which she enjoyed as well.  The takeout portion could be bigger but it's filling.

As far the restaurant itself, it's TINY and always crowded.  I'm talking small quarters, but you forget how small it is once you start eating.

I must mention that today, we ordered takeout and were told it would be ready in 20 minutes.  We left the office 10 minutes after placing the call and it took 10 minutes for us to walk there.  When we arrived, the food wasn't ready and we ended up waiting an additional 20 minutes for our takeout.  We could've just ate there by that time.  

Aside from this snafu, I'll remain a patron as long as the food remains consistent.
author: Sarah B.

description:
For less than $10 for good Thai food, this is the place to go.  I highly recommend the Thai BBQ Chicken, on the lunch-rice plate menu.

My only complaint is that the place is a little old and run down and the portions are small.
author: M O.

description:
First off, the food is solidly good here.  However, there are other things to take into consideration.

My husband and I met for lunch here and decided to go easy on the wallet.  We figured we would order 1 appetizer and 1 entree.  How much do you think that would cost?

At CLG Thai Cafe, it came out to $28 (after tax and tip).  Let me tell you exactly what we got:

- The Angel Wings appetizer (stuffed, boneless chicken wings).  The WIngS (plural) meant that we got TWO wings.  At $8.50 for this appetizer we thought we might get, oh, at least 4?  So $4.25 per wing.  I was mad when I saw the dish being delivered to our table.

- Some spicy beans and beef sautee that was a lunch item.  The lunch item was $8.75 but we opted for the entree that was an additional $1. (Total: $9.75)  The dish that arrived was tiny for an "entree".   I swear it was approximately 2 measuring cups of food scooped into a small oval dish.

- Since we ordered the entree, we also ordered 1 serving of white rice: $2.  For $2 this was really jacked up -- it was approximately 1 measuring cup of rice.

- 1 water (free) and 1 soda: $2.

We tipped our waiter (in full - since none of this could be blamed on her).  

Total: $28 for a light lunch.

Never again.

(Wow, I just read my previous review and nothing has changed.. shame on me for making the same mistake twice.)
author: Spicy T.

description:
If there's one thing I'm tired of seeing in reviews for Thai and Indian places, it's complaints about the high spiciness of the food.  If you want bland food, go to Chuck's House of Bland Midwestern Cuisine.  Some of us are actually craving a dish that has pepper in it, as opposed to merely waved in the general vicinity.  I have a general problem when going to "ethnic" restaurants, which is that the servers take one look at the white guy and decide that I can't handle spicy food; as a result, no matter how much spice I order, I usually wind up getting something that almost approaches thinking about the consideration of approximating a mild tang.  I have even had this problem with Chili Lemon Garlic when dining in, but I've discovered that, when I've ordered online, it's impossible for them to discern my ethnicity.  Rejoice!

In any case, I am generally a fan of the overall flavor and portions of the food.  My most recent dining experience, in which I ordered panang nua Thai spicy, blew me away.  Many Thai restaurants in San Francisco will present panang nua as a lot of beef in overly-sweet peanut sauce with a few sad slices of red bell pepper.  This curry was done right:  spicy, with a nice assortment of veggies included with the beef, and by "spicy," I mean sweat was rolling off my brow and my endorphins were surging in a way I have not experienced in far too long.  I couldn't stop eating the sauce even though my mouth was rebelling and warning me of dire consequences.

One can get better Thai food in terms of flavor balance and quality of ingredients, but Chili Lemon Garlic really hits the spot when you want a potent, flavorful dish, and I'd much rather patronize it than a place like Osha which tempers its food to appeal to the hipster crowd.
author: Bitter J.

description: Let's say you want Pizza. Do you think Pizza Hut is good pizza? It had all the ingredients that go into Pizza, so surely it's good pizza! But you know what the problem with Pizza Hut is? It doesn't charge twice as much as one of those stupid non-chain places. Don't you wish Pizza Hut cost way more than a hand tossed, pizza made by someone who gave a damn? Also, what if we were talking about thai food instead of pizza, and we for some reason you kept calling Chili Lemon Garlic Pizza Hut. Well, then this is your place!
author: Jonah B.

description:
Look, I know I can't be too picky around this part of the city, if I'm not willing to fork over $25 for lunch. I work in the area, and I've simply got to deal.

This place is a welcome addition to the seeming dearth of quality eateries around Third and Bryant. Never mind the boring (but far from bland) name.

Ordered lunch to go from here today, and I'm not turned off, but I doubt I'll be going back too often, if at all.

They let me order Pad Kee Mow, even though it didn't appear on the menu. That's cool of them. I don't like when restaurants won't make something, despite the fact that you can piece together from the menu that they have all the requisite ingredients. It's like they have round beef patties, lettuce, tomato, onions, hamburger buns, and mustard, but refuse to make a hamburger. Fuck that.

Anyway, the food was tasty enough, the portions were just right. But there was an overarching normality to it all.

And at $10 a pop, um, thanks, but no thanks.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This place deserves way better reviews than the two it has received.  I HIGHLY recommend that anyone interested in good Thai food give this place a try.

First, let me comment on the other reviews.  One says that charging $2.50 for a side of rice is ridiculous.  Sure, if it is plain white rice, but they failed to mention that all of their rice is brown Jasmine rice.  Also, if you want to go to one of the many chain restaurants you might find something cheaper, but I'd rather support a family run business. 

I went here last week and have nothing but good things to say:

*Unique menu with many different choices
*Great presentation 
*Very flavorful and FRESH seafood
*The owners were exceptionally friendly
*One of the few (good) places open in SOMA late night

We spoke with the owners about why they moved from their old location in the Mission.   The landlord tried to triple their rent which forced them to move to SOMA where they found a smaller place to rent for a better price.   That said, they seem to be making the best of it and had GREAT attitudes.  I will definitely be back!
author: Carlyna R.

description: This place has the one of the best Green Curries in the city! The portions are small and they can be a little over priced. But when I'm really craving amazing Green Curry with Brown Rice. This is where I go.
author: Natasha S.

description:
During my extended trip to Thailand last year, a local friend of mine introduced me to haw mok (spelled homok here, but pronounced more like my spelling). I love all Thai food, but this was my favorite dish on my vacation. Since then, i have looked all over southern CA for it, unsuccessfully. On my trip to SF, i finally found a place which served it.  It is basically steamed fish curry, with a mousse-like consistency.  CLG's version was a little different from what I had in Thailand, served on a scallop, but not on a banana leaf. It was very good and I highly recommend for anyone to try it. You can split it as an appetizer or get it with rice as a meal(their brown rice is also good). 

Overall, I really enjoyed this place. It is very casual and cozy. My BF's noodle soup was also very flavourful and unique. It is an easy walk from downtown or the baseball stadium. The prices were very fair for SF.
author: Kris J.

description: I normally like to give restaurants at least 3 stars, but unfortunately, that just wasn't quite possible for Chili Lemon Garlic.  The place definitely gets kudos for the clean, cozy interior, the convenient location near work, and the fact that they take phone orders for takeout.  Aside from that, the food is lacking.  I've gotten the pad thai or pad see eu for a quick lunch, but it's a bit greasy, and portion sizes are too small...I was still hungry after eating! Furthermore, I only had at most, 2 pieces of beef in my pad see ew supposedly with beef.  2 small pieces at that.  Also, the prices were pretty high, not really worth it.  I probably will be back every so often due to its convenience, but I personally favor Koh Samui or Osha Thai more.
author: K C.

description:
Here is the deal - this place probably has the best soup within many blocks.  For $7.50, it is really hard to beat this place.  I get the Thai boat noodle soup.  It's just spicy enough to make you sniffle like crazy, but with enough flavor to make you sip all the broth.  Ingredients are pretty fresh and it's definitely a made to order type place.  Things take a bit of time to come out of the kitchen.  You probably want to have a bit of time if you come here for lunch.  The fried chicken over rice is good, but kind of pricey when compared to my favorite places.  Considering Koh Samui and Osha Thai is within a couple blocks, I would probably prefer either of those for regular thai dishes...maybe I just need to try a few more things here.   

Anyhow, it's a regular lunch spot which says a lot.
author: Simon Y.

description:
Now that I have officially banned Koh Samui and the Monkey, I had to find another joint to give me my Thai food fix.  So i remembered seeing signs for CLG and decided to give these guys a shot.  

I had their duck fried rice for dinner the other day.  It was pretty good!  It wasn't too salty like most other thai places.  Prices were ok (not great) and best of all they have online ordering and delivery options!  Great for folks living in the restaurant-deprived SoBe.  

I'd give them 4 stars but the service was pretty poor.  They are nice and all but just seemed sub standard and lacking professionalism.  I've gotten better service at hole in the wall chinese restaurants.

Looking forward to trying out the rest of their menu and coming back for an updated review.  For now, we'll hold her steady at 3 stars.
author: Caesar C.

description:
Meh. I've experienced better.  Price for a thai boat noodle was $7.50 i think?  Pretty decent amount of noodle and almost enough broth for the noodle ratio.  Noodles were the right consistency the whole way through.  My sentiments mirror Kelly H. in that soup was a bit bland for this type of dish, and meats were tough and chewy = gross.

I'd say based on just the thai boat noodle, I'll not be coming back.  but maybe their other dishes are better?  better thai boat noodle can be found elsewhere in the City.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Order the Cashew Chicken for lunch, and be in a happy place for 10-15 minutes. There is no other Thai place anywhere that makes Cashew Chicken even remotely as good as CLG (or "little thai" as our startup called it). 

There dinner menu is different, so this is purely a lunch recommendation. Go early if you have more than 4 people.
author: Peter S.

description: I come here quite often, and they rarely disappoint. Given the other Thai Places I've tried in the area, I think it's fair to give CLG a 4 star, vs. the other horrible places that are getting 4 stars.
author: Roxy G.

description:
when: weekday, lunch

I'm very captivated by the name. It seems a few words thrown together to be a restaurant name. The restaurant's only half a block away from work, so its very convenient for me to go there for lunch. Though the place does get a little noisey when large groups of coworkers from another company are dining.

I dont think I've been here enough to give it a full 4-star rating, but its pretty close. I've ordered the Duck Noodle Soup and to my surprise, it came with authentic Thai noodle. I've only had it with a dinner noodle, but this noodle was kind of wavey and came in some clumps. The duck is good, not too fatty. The soup was delicious and seasoned to an appropriate amount. Absolutely perfect for the rainy day.

I've also tried their Tom Kar which was delicious. I dont usually eat this so I dont have much to compare with.

The restaurant is a little on the smaller side, but nicely decorated. They had really nice napkins that were thick and colorful--unlike most restaurants that have the usual thin rectangular ones. Service was good, nothing notable though.

They also deliever on grubhub.com too, so that's a plus. But minus half a star for not covering all of SOMA. The restaurant's on Bryant and 3rd, and we were on Clementina and 5th. I can walk that distance in 15 minutes. The more I think about it, the more disappointed I am about their small delivery radius.
author: Rena Y.

description: This is a tiny place, thought of trying it out as I walk past it almost everyday. First of, I was surprised at the pricing. I've been to much better Thai restaurants (in terms of ambience, popularity, size etc)  that are cheaper. Second I was disappointed at the portions. I tried the Crab fried rice, but I can't be paying $10 for it and still feel hungry! The dish was actually pretty good, simple and flavorful. I might try them again, maybe for lunch.
author: Rohit N.

description:
This place is pretty good. Glad to have a Thai place so nearby my work that is not too crazy or expensive and satisfies my common Thai food cravings.

Their pad thai is tasty, and their Praram is also quite tasty, if a bit on the watery side. But there's lots of veggies sitting in that peanut sauce, which I really appreciate. Too many Thai food places make their Praram with nothing but peanut sauce a spinach leaf (maybe even two) and a bunch of cabbage. Mine from Chili Lemon Garlic had broccoli, carrot, cabbage, plenty of spinach, and plenty of the chicken that I ordered. A satisfying lunch, although, again, a bit on the watery side.
author: Alyssa P.

description: We come here all the time... we had  the calamari and cashew chicken.  They were both great  - but better than that - their service is phenomenal!  I mean how many places serve Thai - a million - but how about a place where they care that you are there and it is delicious!  High five to CLG!!!
author: Toni H.

description:
This is a review only for Delivery. I have never been inside this place. I just happened to run across their menu in my lobby and went for it.

As you will see by my below order, I am by no means a Thai Food Specialist. 
I ordered:
Thai Satay (chicken) - $7.25
Red Curry with Chicken - $8.95
That Hot Basil with Chicken - $8.75
2 orders of Jasmine Rice - $3.00

It was delicious!  Very fresh and tasty. They also delivered it very quickly.

I will order from them again when I get too lazy to cook. (which will probably be any day now)
author: Christine S.

description:
OK so I really wanted to like this place. It's right around the corner from the office AND they deliver. Score. But the first time I went I wasn't thrilled. The tom yum soup wasn't tangy enough, the shrimp rolls were not what I expected (I thought they would be more like egg rolls - they were more like fried shrimp with a wrapper), and the chicken with spicy chili tasted like it was previously frozen and had that funny freezer burn flavor.

But...I didn't yelp it the first time because like I said...I really, really wanted to like it. So I went back today. I got the larb salad with beef. You know that salad...the one with lettuce and mint and onions and that yummy tangy spicy dressing with steak on top? So yeah, that all happened - except it was ground beef instead of steak. I don't want ground beef in my salad. Well, let me rephrase that - I don't want ground beef in my salad UNLESS it's a taco salad. Which it clearly wasn't. So not so happy with CLG visit part deux.

Sigh.

I'll probably go back here again just for the sake of convenience. I mean, they have a ton of stuff on their menu - but so far I'm not impressed. And with Koh Samui & the Monkey one block away, they've got some pretty mean competition...
author: Kate S.

description:
i think when the op said the cost of brown rice was "ridiculous" he meant it in a good way

I'm so happy this place is here! The food is good. It has good flavor, and its a good portion. It was a little skimp on the meat, but I bought some rice noodles from the store and a pre-cooked chicken and made like 3 more meals out of all the sauce. 

The only thing I would not rec is the tom yum soup. It lacked any depth of flavor or savory flavor. The papaya salad was only ok, would not have it again. We had it delivered, perfectly fresh and hot, but it took an hour. Now, to be fair, they told us it would be an hour and we said ok.

I'm just really happy to have another great ethnic place in this area bc Primo Patio (on Townsend btwn 3rd and 4th- for caribbean food,jerk chix is AMAZING! I eat there 3 times a week, they open at 9am but close at 4pm, not open Sundays unless there is a game. You HAVE TO go and try a jerk chix sandwich w red fries. OMG!!!- anyway, I digress) is the only other place and it is a good option if it's after 4pm or a Sunday :)

I know everyone is tight on money these days, but I thought their prices were fair. It wasn't cheap, but you know, they have bills to pay too. The food was fresh and convenient. I'll pay $30 for 2 entrees, a soup, papaya salad, noodles and rice. I'm a fan and I wish them well!
author: cali c.

description:
Sort of a weird name for a Thai restaurant, but anyway...

This place can be crowded, like the Malaysian restaurant that it used to be.  When there's a full house inside, you might feel a bit claustrophobic.

So I gave this place my Pad See Ew test, and it passes.  Unfortunately, it took them a longer time than normal to cook, for some reason.  At least the bowl and wooden chopsticks that they give you were a nice touch.

The price was a bit more than I expected also, but I wouldn't say that it was expensive, as you do get just enough value for the food.

I suppose I'll come back here to try their other stuff, like their soups or rice dishes.
author: Marlon E.

description:
Interesting restaurant name, as my dish didn't come with anything with chili, lemon, or garlic in it. Apparently, it came with the wrong sauce too. But despite these minor confusions, I give this place a 3-star because it's pretty decent. I'm glad there's another dining choice around my office, because I was getting tired of the other options. 

They have a decent selection. I ordered the fried chicken over fried rice, because I'm a sucker for anything fried rice. The chicken was standard, juicy enough, and not over fried. The rice... "ok." I've had better fried rice, but it's also much better than many places I've been to. Their duck noodle soup also smelled really good - that's probably what I'll be eating next time. Their portions are not super XXL sized, and not diet-sized, so I say just right for lunch. 

If you've never been, and are looking for different places to try around the area, I say it's worth the shot.
author: Kevin T.

description: Today I was hungry for some Thai food because my friend was talking about it the other day. I decided to try this place since it was close to my work and since it was quiet at the time,  I knew the food would be prepared quickly. I ended up ordering Pad Thai and a Thai Ice Tea. It ended up costing me around $15 with tip. The Pad Thai looked delicious when it arrived but it is definitely not the best I've had. It was bland for my tastebuds but I still enjoyed it.  Maybe they didn't add the MSG or something which is nice considering that I hate the MSG additive but sadly, I had a mediocre Pad Thai. I would probably come here again but I would suggest adding some hot sauce or something to the Pad Thai to give it an extra kick. The food isn't exactly cheap either....and it's not in a prime location... but then again SOMA is not a relatively cheap place to dine so it wasn't that big of a problem for me.
author: Jonathon C.

description: it'd take me all my fingers and toes to count how many times i've been to this place.  it's out of convenience ande maybe coworker's choice that keeps bringing me back here.  it's definitely not the food.  i won't say it's terrible--mediocre might be appropriate, but the service is pretty good here.  they're diligent with the waters, take your orders right away  they even bring you your drink with a little rose made out of the straw sleeve.  :)
author: Terri M.

description:
Came here for lunch with a group of 5 from the office. Be warned -- it's *small*. I'm used to SF eateries being preternaturally tiny, but this is pushing it -- they had to move another, smaller group to another table in order to squeeze us in... After that service was fairly slow, but we weren't in a hurry. :)

I was quite happy with the food -- I had the pumpkin/prawn/chicken golden curry special with brown rice and (of course) a Thai iced tea. The curry was flavorful and spicy without killing me, and there was enough of everything for me to feel satisfied without having an overfull plate.

Based on this meal I'd definitely try the *food* again, but I'm not sure I'd make a habit of eating in, what with the tiny tiny dining room.

They do offer delivery, which might get tried some time... Delivery area appears to extend from SOMA all the way out to Castro/Noe.

Note there's a $20 minimum for credit cards according to the menu (this might be delivery only, but I'm not sure).
author: Brion V.

description: I've only eaten here once but the veggie praram and brown rice was incredible. And the waitress is one of the friendliest, most polite and happy people I've ever had the pleasure of speaking to.
author: Rebecca G.

description: YUM!  I've only had take out twice here but damn was it good.  The Thai spicy pan fried noodles were hot and delicious.  It's flat rice noodles stir fried with choice of meat (I had ground chicken), fresh tomatoes, mushroom, onions, basil, chili in black bean sauce.  My coworkers all wanted a taste!  The Heavenly Prawns were quite tasty also.
author: P.J. D.

description:
I loved you guys when you were in the Mission! Personal favorites are the crispy shrimp rolls, and the Pad See Eu With Tofu. LOVE the Thai Iced Tea and Green Tea ice Cream as well. 

When I found out you were leaving the Mission because of your trifling landlords and their very underhanded move in kicking you out, I was very sad. I remember walking by where you used to be and hanging my head low. 

Then I ended up having a meeting with City Models, and just after signing with them at their office Downtown I saw a sign out of the corner of my eye that read "CLG." I wandered over and there you were! 

You are back in my life and back in my tummy and I couldn't be happier about that! All of you are AMAZING people and I am so glad you are doing well in your new location.
author: Chantelle T.

description:
i still come here once a week because it's so close to my office.

but dear 8 pound 5 ounces baby jesus, can they just tone down the heat in those dishes!  9/10 times i ask for NOT SPICY, and yet i start crying as soon as the food touches my lips.

stubborn fool that i am, i still try to tell them NOT SPICY each time 10 different ways with little success.
author: Josie M.

description:
Woke up from my afternoon nap craving some shrimp, and tried to think of yummy shrimp I could get my hands on.  Unfortunately what came to mind was the Dancing Prawns from CLG, which up and moved out of my hood with no warning (damn evil landlords!).  Those were some of the yummiest shrimp, despite the labor of having to take all their little shells off (which would normally be a real turn-off for me).

As I was grumpily figuring out what my plan B was my heart sank, realizing that THE BEST SOUP EVER was no longer within my easy reach.  Their Kang Jerd soup - awesome little pork meatballs, and sweet sweet cabbage and onions, floating in this most amazingly seasoned broth.  I have no idea what spices were in there, but I've never had anything like it.  Very mysterious, and freakin delicious.

Now I'm just depressed.

I don't know if their menu (or their food) has changed since their move, but I would definitely recommend picking up some Kang Jerd or some Dancing Prawns next time you're there.  If they're even close to how yummy they were before then you should be pleased.

Why only 3 stars, if I'm so enamored?  Well, I also used to LOVE their Pad See Eu, but it became somewhat hit or miss, along with some of their other dishes I got regularly.  So that was starting to bum me out.  

And they lose another star for moving away.  Although since it was apparently not their fault I should probably give it back.  Maybe once I find out how to get me some sweet sweet Kang Jerd I will.  Mmmm... I can almost smell it now.
author: g. g.

description: Very few restaurants actually live in the "freeway blocks" between Bryant and Harrison, but CLG is one of them.  Easy to miss, but being so small (the smallest Thai place I've seen in SF), it can still fill up.  Vibe is homey, but nicely decorated.  Pineapple fried rice is delish, Thai Iced Tea is satisfactory, panang is unremarkable.  Also, it seems like they use the dinner menu (and hence dinner prices) for lunch.  And a $2 surcharge for faux meat?  Seriously?  Don't they know how much less energy it takes to make than real meat?
author: Wes M.

description: Have had take-out from this place 2 times now and am very satisfied with the quality of the food.  The noodles, curry and apps have all been very delicious.  The only downside is that it's a bit pricey which would be okay but the portion sizes are a little small for the price tag.
author: Carly P.

description:
This is a cute little place for grabbing a tasty lunch. The Golden Curry lunch special is excellent: red curry with chicken, pumpkin and tofu. Recommended.

Delivery for dinner was not as impressive, in my one experience. For one thing, the fabulous Golden Curry isn't on the dinner menu. I wonder why not? The pad thai I ordered was good, but pretty average as far as Thai delivery goes.

I'll stick with dine-in lunch.
author: Matt B.

description: This is a cozy neighborhood joint where the quick and tasty dishes combined with friendly service warm you from the inside out.  No need to dress up at this good value place; it's easy on the taste buds and wallet.
author: OneOfTwo F.

description: I only get delivery and have never been to the restaurant in person. Their crab fried rice is awesome, but one thing that irritates me to no end is they NEVER give you chopsticks. How am I supposed to eat my takeout?
author: K D.

description:
Been here twice, once as dine-in and once as take-out.  The first experience was solid, almost comparable to nearby Koh Samui but at a lower price, and in less luxe surroundings.  

More recently, had the Jungle Curry, which is a coconut-less curry from Northern Thailand.  Tasty, healthy alternative to your typical curries.  But even better was the spicy stir fried noodles.
author: Greg K.

description: So I went back again a couple of days ago, and I feel like I need to bump the rating up a bit. I had the daily special - Golden Curry, which was pumpkin, chicken, and tofu in red curry. It was quite good. Definitely more strongly spiced than the yellow curry I had a few days before, and there were also more veggies, and a wider variety this time. Also, the decor is a little nicer than I gave the impression in my first review - think Target wall decor and a fairly competent job of sponge-painting. Still nothing special, but a step up from a Tenderloin hole in the wall.
author: Dave C.

description:
sooo good!
we have been getting the eggplant with tofu, red curry, pad thai and brown rice. I love it, great food and they are particular about cooking meat/veggie dishes! they know what they're talking about when you say you're vegetarian (no fish sauce, etc).
only thing is - I wish they delivered outside of soma! please expand your radius!! that's the only reason it's missing a star!
author: bhavna p.

description: Pleasant good Thai food.  A bit busy during the weekday 12-1, but clears up after 1pm.
author: Alex S.

description:
I was so psyched to find a low-key Thai place close to where I live.  I normally go to Bangkok Noodle at Union Square.

I ordered noodle soups; 1). with fish balls and minced pork, 2). Yen-ta-foh which is a seafood noodle soup in the red bean curd sauce.  They turned out to be great disappointment in many ways.  Seriously these are so easy to make, how could you not have the right ingredients.  Everything that was put in these dishes were wrong.  

1). Fish ball and minced pork noodle soup - Starting from the missing minced pork, so I only got fishballs and noodles....really?  

2). Yen ta foh only came with 2 little shrimps, 1 little block of imitation crab and a couple of leaves of greens.  This soup normally comes with calamari, fish balls, shrimp, and maybe imitation crab.  On top of that, the soup tasted like they put the red tamarind sauce that's used for pad thai in my noodle as a supplement to the red bean curd sauce.  Again....really...are you kidding me?  

3). The portion - the portion is half of what you normally get at Thai House Express or Bangkok Noodle but it cost more at CLG.  I understand that everything in the Loin is cheaper and I wouldn't have complained about the portion if it at least was done right..... but it wasn't.

Sorry to complain but this blew my mind.  I guess they were expecting to not cater to real Thai people so you wouldn't know what was supposed to be in each dish.  I wonder how they got 4 & 5 stars from some reviewer.  Maybe they're good at some dishes and not at others.  If that's the case....they should just drop the "others" that they're not so good at.

Soooo disappointed!!!!!!  I guess I'm back to walking to Union square to get low-key real Thai food.
author: T. J.

description: Upgrading my previous review from four stars to five.  It seems strange to base an entire rating on one dish, but despite my searching, I can't find a single Thai dish that I enjoy as much as their golden curry.  Half of my office now orders it on a fairly consistent basis.  My previous review cited less-than-stellar service; however, the staff took note of my review and have really stepped up their game.  Plus, they are finally willing to make my food as spicy as I like it (although they'll probably still be skeptical of anyone else asking for something "as spicy as you can make it").
author: Kyle H.

description: I should have went to Koh Samui.  Tried the golden curry which was supposed to be one of their popular dishes.  Small portions for and $11 plate and the pumpkin was tough and chewey.  I won't be back.
author: G A.

description: Another "hole in the wall"...one of my favorite places now.  I recommend the Thai Seafood Noodle Soup or Green Curry!  This is THE place to go for Thai food, since it's a rarity around South Park/MOMA
author: Danielle Y.

description: If there's one thing this super-agent can't stand about some Asian restaurants, it's being skimpy with meat.  When I pay $10 for a really small order of Pad Thai, I expect to see more than THREE average-sized prawns.  And when I pay $10 for Red Curry Chicken, I expect to see more than two sad little spoon-fulls of chicken drowning in a quart of sauce.  I don't mind paying handsomely for a good meal but this was ridiculous.  This will be the last time I order from CLG.  Period.
author: Ari G.

description: I am definitely a fan of this place!  I have only been there a handful of times and each time better than the last.  I have had the bbq chicken, bbq pork, and pad thai, all 3 were good.  Their thai iced tea was good as well....The only problem I  had with the place is that the restaurant is small, and not very great for big groups.  Another thing that I didn't like too much was that the portions of food aren't very big - so you might want to try some appetizers.
author: Chris L.

description: ive had #52, pad thai and the fried chicken. they were all really good. they dont come that spicy so if ur like me and want ur nose to run while ur eating ur noodles, order extra, extra spicy with spicy sauce on the side just in case and throw in some sriracha if u want ur mouth to burn. this is how i like my spicy food. the restaurant is very small and the wait is long to get ur food but i usually go around lunch time when its busy. order take-out, its easier. a little pricey but if u cant afford, then just dont go.
author: vicki g.

description: Have gone here a few times and the food is pretty darn good. The big problem is that the portions are super small, especially when you're ordering take out.  I'm not a big eater at all and can get full off a bag of Cheetos, so the fact that I'm still hungry after a meal here, means that their portions aren't even enough for the average person.   Another minus is their price.  I paid $9.50 for a stir fried noodle that was enough to fill up one of those cups you get at a drinking fountain and nothing else.  I'm torn here, because the food is quite good so 3 stars is about right.
author: Milton W.

description: I don't think I'll get delivery from them again. I got the Thai Spicy Pan Fried Noodles and they were very bland, slightly mushy, extremely oily, and the fried tofu tasted a little rancid. The spring rolls were alright, nothing special.
author: Mel L.

description: I am from Chicago so maybe I do not know what is good but this place had the best pad thai I have ever had.  I did not try any other Thai places while I was in San Francisco.  I totally crave this place but I live in Chicago so too bad for me :(.
author: Megan P.

description: Came here for dinner. It was really good, and the staff was friendly. I got all my favorites (larb and pad see ew). Good if you want a more casual alternative to Koh Samui and the Monkey. Food is just as good if not better.
author: Nathan M.

description:
I had been there for three times. Love the satay, beef was tender. Coconut soup, yummy. Red curry also great. Fried rice... there are too many bad ones in SF and I'll give this one a B,  The food here is not extraordinary but good enough to make me and my friends happy. I'm not Thai and don't know if it's genuine or not, but it tastes pretty close to the more high end Thai restaurants here.
It does seem like they only have one waitress usually but  when I was there they weren't busy so service was good to me.  
Good to find a nice Thai restaurant in that part of the city.   One thing I really don't like is the fountain near the window.. it hasn't been cleaned for a long time and it stinks. And the confusing name.
author: YEQIN S.

description: Nice spot for thai food.   Good egg rolls and quick service.    Overall- I give 3.5 stars.
author: D S.

description:
Four stars because I prefer their cozy ambiance to the noisy clamoring of Koh Samui. Service is friendly and fairly prompt. Portions, while not overly large, are satisfying. And with Thai food, I find that "satisfying" is about all you can hope for in terms of quantity.

Had the Pad See Ew. The noodles and egg meshed together delicately. Will be back for more. Also curious to see if they deliver.
author: Mia L.

description: I will admit CLG is a bit pricey. It took me a while to order delivery from them, due to previous reviews. However, I have found CLG to use the freshest ingredients of any thai restaurant around. Their dishes are prepared quite well and are not over seasoned, which I find true of most thai restaurants. Their portion size is ample, not cheap chinese food size, but not skimpy. I enjoy CLG and feel that it is worth the cost.
author: Ginger K.

description: basil chicken was bland and reminiscent of ground soy or mush.  fried chicken over rice sounds tasty but that's as far as it goes; it's compressed thigh meat in a greasy breading.  i love thai food and this place didn't make the grade tonight.  we won't be trying again.
author: Jon H.

description: SOOO GROSS!!!! DONT EAT HERE. They delivered the food late. There was a hair in my stuffed wings. And a dead beetle in my curry. NEVER AGAIN. VOMIT.
author: Shawne B.

description: I've been here several times, almost once a week and I've never been dissappointed.  The portions are a little on the small side, but the food is great and always fresh.  I've been especially impressed with the quality of their seafood dishes.
author: Sam N.

description:
Today is our first time here.

I must say I expected a really whole in the wall restaurant given its location. But I was impressed by the simple, yet some what trendy decor on one wall and traditional paintings on the other.

We eat Thai food almost once a week and know what we like. Today we order the usual,-Papaya Salad, BBQ Beef and Curry Seafood Combo, Thai ice tea. All were good. The Seafood was a bit on the spicy side.

The price was a bit on the pricey side. Every dish we ordered  for dinner was over $11 with small portion. I expected it to be under $10 for its location. I expected it to be our neighborhood restaurant. 

But I have to say, the food was tasty, a bit better than Monkey ...on Brannan St. 

We will go back to try the lunch,
author: Kathy P.

description: I tried the Thai Spicy Pan Fried Noodles (flat rice noodles stir fried with choice of meat fresh tomatoes, mushroom, onions, basil chili in black bean sauce). They were very good. i wish the portions were a little bigger though. Service wasn't that great though.
author: Retired B.

description: this restaurant no longer honored the restaurant.com gift certificates.  i went to the restaurant because of it and left angry because they did not honor it.  another restaurant that abuses the restaurant.com lure.  very dissatisfied.
author: Jim D.

description: I called in at 6:15 my deliver order. 45min to and hour they tell me. That totally normal here  cool. At 7:30 I called back inquiring about my order. She explained that it was raining, and it was, and that orders are taking about a half hour longer than usual to arrive. Called again at 8:15. "The guy is leaving right now," she says. When the food showed up at 8:25,  not only was the order incorrect, but it was cold. Immediately I called the restaurant back and said, "please come and pick this food up. Its incorrect and the food is cold. I just want my money back." She then responded with, "OK, don't eat the food. We'll be back around 11:00 to pick the food up and refund your money." I never got ahttp://www.clgthaicafe.com/called back tonight. Spoke with man on the phone about my reimbursement and he knew nothing of it due to the fact that lady I spoke with the night before wasn't working attest evening. Meanwhile the entire time the gentleman and I were speaking you could hear a lady in the back round saying, "We no pay! We no pay!  I then told the man if they don't refund my money back in the next couple hours, I would report them. They said, "Go right ahead and report us for COLD FOOD!" This is bad business. I hope that the BBB looks into the how the business is ran and any other customers they have blemished before Chili Lemon Garlic of San Francisco is eligible for any BBB awards or accommodations.
author: Mike W.

description: Good mango curry, pad thai. A little expensive.
author: John K.

description: They're former location was better.  I rate a 4 overall.  We liked the friendly service by the 1 server there, who was very nice and also cute.  But that's besides the point.  I ordred the duck fried rice which is very tasty and the portion is just right.    I'd recommend a visit and see for yourself.  If I have a taste for Thai and in the area, I'll go to this place.  Not the hippest spot or the most romantic dining room but a stop for decent grub.
author: De M.

description: small restaurant in a grundgy area that has decent decor and nice authentic thai accents. the food was good (pad see eu was delicious, spicy garlic chicken was too spicy but had good flavor) but not as cheap as i would like for the neighborhood. mostly a take-out/delivery place. don't like how they charge extra for tea and rice.
author: I. K.
